body.p: Sunday 5 July '85
My dear Mr Morais

Many thanks for your
letter—I understand the man
concerning whose burial I wrote
you, was not circumcised, but inquiry
is to be made as to whether this is so or not.

The proof had not arrived
why my letter to you was sent off--
I enclose them now—you need not
trouble to return them--

Dr Kohler may even yet
turn out conservative, simply from the
fact that he is a most erratic genius, and
writes[insertion made by author] without thinking of facts on behalf of reform
upon His radicalism is mischievous
unless answered—it then becomes laughable.
I hope Dr Kohert will persevere.

With regards [?]
H. Pereira Mendes
Thanks for slips returned.
To The American Hebrew.

Dr. Kohler recently published in the New
York Herald a sermon in which he made mis-
statements , unjust insinuations against orthodox
Judaism, and by representing that the orthodox
Hebrews did not sufficiently exalt moral law,
supplied a weapon useful to those who still
nourish a prejudice against our nation. I an-
swered in the same columns, in order that
something might be done to correct the mischief
where it was perpetrated, though it was very
distasteful to bring forward such topics in the
Christian press. Dr. Kohler replied to me,
again in the Herald. Sooner than continue the
struggle in the secular press I ask to use the
columns of THE AMERICAN HEBREW, which of
all the Jewish papers, has given most space to
this controversy. Dr. Kohler divides his letter
into numbered paragraphs:--I treat them ac-
cordingly:

1. As to my charge that Dr. Kohler's asser-
tion, " I do not think that to eat pork or oysters
is a sin that can in any way compare with lying
or cheating," was with its context, as much as to
say that the orthodox Jews did think so; and
my remark that such an insinuation might pre-
judice orthodox Jews in the eyes of Christians
reading it in the Herald.

Dr. Kohler in his answer admits he does "not
deal with the moral views of 'his' orthodox co-
religionists, and had not the least intention of
speaking disparagingly of their condition in
comparison with reform Jews." I thank him
for this admission. But he ends this paragraph
I as follows: "I did not only insinuate but said
explicitly in my discourse, 'According to the
Talmudic maxim, it was a greater crime to eat
pork or oysters than to lie and cheat." Ordi-
nary readers will infer that the Talmud makes
this direct assertion. It is not the case. Why
mislead people into thinking so?--and especially
Christians?

Paragraph 2 he devotes to an ingenious but
more than faulty method of reasoning, to prove
that the Talmud regards moral law as inferior
to ceremonial. He admits it "knows absolutely
as far as the practical noun (Halacha) goes, of
no distraction between moral and ceremonial
law," but he argues it from the relative punish-
ment, and especially cites those "upon which
stands the penalty of thirty-nine stripes." As a
matter of fact this punishment was afflicted not
only for eating pork and oysters, as the Doctor
states, that is to say, not only for infringement
upon ceremonial law, but for infringement
upon certain moral laws also (see Maccoth 13 a).
Qui concumbit cum sorore sud cum arcita, cum a
m
materata, cum sorore uxoris etc. The Doctor
also states that "he who eats leavened bread on
Passover is guilty of extermination." This is
incorrect. The penalty is excision. (See Exod.
xii., 15,19). What the punishment of excision
means is doubtful. R. Bechai in Biur Nattorah
has something to say about it; so has Abarbanel
in his comment on Numb. xx, 30, where he
speaks of the difference of opinion among our
sages on this point, and quotes half a dozen.
Rashi, Maimonides and Nachmanides and others
have their opinions also. But whatever it is, it
is a penalty not only for eating leavened bread
on Passover, for not observing circumcision,
(Gen. xv., 11,14); on the Day of Atonement,
(Levit.xxiii., 29,30), etc., that is to say, not
only for infringement upon ceremonial laws, but
for infringement upon moral laws, (see Levit.
xviii., 29;xx., 17) ^ [Added by author in margin in ink: Thus the same punishment is applied to breach of ceremonial and moral law]. Dr. Kohler's argument on
the punishment basis does not, therefore, apply
here. But it is most startling to find the Doctor
soberly intimating that orthodoxy ever placed
insufficient stress on moral law, when he knows
that all the "ten commandments," the very pith
of the whole Torah in orthodox eyes, refer to
moral law; even the 4th, by its sanctification of
a day for moral culture.

Paragraphs 3 and 4. Says Dr. Kohler: "I
cannot share the fear of the reverend gentlemen
that the statement which he forced me to make
will nourish prejudice." I did not force him to
make any statements. Everything he said or
wrote was said or written before I even took up
the pen or spoke. And he is wrong to trust too
much to Beechers and Newtons, or the press.
They do not prevent some of the aristocratic
private schools being closed to Hebrew children,. Or the expression of unfriendly and illiberal sen-
timent too often heard by Hebrew merchants
from Christian lips, or the intolerant sentiment
too often heard by Hebrew merchants from
Christian lips, or the] intolerant sentiment ex-
pressed in society so frequently.

Paragraph 5. The famous "pork and oyster"
phrase. Dr. Kohler may, if he likes, trace our
food laws to customs of the "idol worshipping
priests of Babylon, India and Persia." This
may suit the modern rationalistic school, but it
does not suit those who do not subscribe to it
and who are so irrational as to ask how could
HP Mendes 2

Moses adopt heathen customs when he so con-
stantly warns us against such, and his whole
idea is to make us a distinct people?

In Leviticus, chap.xx. 23 to 26, we find the
food laws are given to separate us from the Ca-
naanite nations—other passages can be quoted.
Dr. Kohler asks: "Are they (the dietary laws)
wise sanitra[editorial mark inserted to reverse order of r and a]y laws?" I assure him they are, and
I [added in margin: h]Sope to add, in due time, a few words to the
opinions of those scientists who assert the wisdom of the laws he questions.

Paragraph 6. Dr. K. remarks: " I do not wish
to monopolize enlightenment and progress for my
reformed brethren." This is all I asked. For
this admission I am really grateful.

Paragraph 7. "I am ready to give the quanti-
tative majority to Rev. H. P. Mendes." This is
all I asked. For Dr.K. intimated that the or-
thodox were in the minority. I am again really
grateful. He concludes by saying that if I am
"so wonderfully proud of the religious condition
of my orthodox section, " he for his part humbly
prays " that the spirit of deeper piety and holier
zeal may take possession of his ^ people, nay of [in margin: [?]]
our whole age," etc., etc. What one thing has to
do with the other is not quite clear to me. I really do not understand the logical connection.
But then I am not one of the modern rationalistic
school; I am only, very truly yours,
H. PEREIRA MENDES.
